heading: 2.3 R Markdown - Reproducible research
text: R Markdown one useful tools applied data analysis allows combine explanatory text executable code single document. key idea simple:write analysis , every time data changes, can re-run document automatically update tables, figures, results.makes work:Automatic: outputs generated code (manually copied).Reproducible: anyone can re-run document obtain results.Well documented: results always accompanied explanations, interpretation, methodology.practice, R Markdown file (.Rmd) works like hybrid report script: contains written text (like Word document) chunks code (like R script). compile (“knit”) file, R executes code chunks inserts results (tables, plots, numbers) directly final report.

heading: 2.7.2.1 Vectors
text: R operates component component, makes straightforward work vectors matrices. Vectors one-dimensional arrays can hold numeric data, character data, logical data, elements must type.create vector, use c() function (stands “concatenate” “combine”):Let’s examine happens add vectors together:Now, let’s consider two vectors different lengths:can check length vector using length() function:happens try add vectors different lengths?IMPORTANT: case, R performs operation anyway, gives us warning lengths differ. R uses “vector recycling,” shorter vector repeated match length longer vector. crucial characteristic vectors can concatenate elements type; otherwise, R coerce elements common type (usually character ’s mix).Let’s explore vector operations:

x <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)

length(x)## [1] 4
length(y)## [1] 3
z <- x + y## Warning in x + y: longer object length is not a multiple of shorter object length

heading: 2.7.2.2 Matrices
text: Matrices two-dimensional arrays elements must type. particularly useful mathematical operations organizing data rows columns.

heading: 2.7.2.2.1 Defining Matrices
text: general syntax creating matrix :create matrices, use matrix() function:necessary explicitly write data=, improves code readability makes intent clearer.Note DEFAULT, R fills matrix column column. can explicitly specify want fill matrix row row using byrow argument:can determine dimensions matrix using dim() function:vector shorter matrix dimensions, R recycle values fill matrix:Note order matrix always rows × columns. can also omit either number rows columns, R calculate missing dimension:creating empty matrices, must define dimensions:
code:
my.matrix <- matrix(vector,
                    ncol = num_columns,
                    nrow = num_rows,
                    byrow = logical_value,
                    dimnames = list(vector_row_names,
                                   vector_column_names))
x <- matrix(data = c(1, 2, 3, 4),
            nrow = 2,
            ncol = 2)

x1 <- matrix(c(1, 2, 3, 4),
             2,
             2)
x##      [,1] [,2]
## [1,]    1    3
## [2,]    2    4
x1##      [,1] [,2]
## [1,]    1    3
## [2,]    2    4
y <- matrix(data = c(1:4),
            nrow = 3,
            ncol = 2,
            byrow = TRUE)## Warning in matrix(data = c(1:4), nrow = 3, ncol = 2, byrow = TRUE): data length [4] is not a sub-multiple or multiple of the number of rows
## [3]
y##      [,1] [,2]
## [1,]    1    2
## [2,]    3    4
## [3,]    1    2
dim(y)## [1] 3 2
dim(y)[1]  # number of rows## [1] 3
dim(y)[2]  # number of columns## [1] 2
y <- matrix(c(1, 2, 3, 4), nrow = 2, ncol = 2, byrow = 2)
y##      [,1] [,2]
## [1,]    1    2
## [2,]    3    4
y <- matrix(c(1, 2, 3, 4), nrow = 2, ncol = 3, byrow = 2)## Warning in matrix(c(1, 2, 3, 4), nrow = 2, ncol = 3, byrow = 2): data length [4] is not a sub-multiple or multiple of the number of columns

heading: 2.8 Arrays
text: Arrays multidimensional data structures extend concept matrices. matrices two-dimensional, arrays can three dimensions. particularly useful working data naturally multiple dimensions, time series data across different regions variables.

heading: 2.8.1 Creating Arrays
text: basic syntax creating array : array(data, dim, dimnames)array dimensions 2 × 4 × 3, meaning 2 rows, 4 columns, 3 “layers” levels third dimension.

                  dimnames = list(dim1, dim2, dim3))
my_array## , , level1

heading: 2.8.3 Accessing Array Elements
text: Arrays can subset using square brackets, similar matrices additional dimensions:
code:
# Access a single element: row 1, column 2, level 3

# Access entire slices
my_array[, , 1]  # All of level 1##      col1 col2 col3 col4
## row1    1    3    5    7
## row2    2    4    6    8
my_array[1, , ]  # All of row 1 across all levels##      level1 level2 level3
## col1      1      9     17
## col2      3     11     19
## col3      5     13     21
## col4      7     15     23
# Access by dimension names
my_array["row1", "col2", "level3"]## [1] 19

heading: 2.9 Lists
text: Lists R’s flexible data structure. Unlike vectors, must contain elements type, lists can contain elements different types, including lists, vectors, matrices, dataframes, even functions.

heading: 2.9.1 Creating Lists
code:
# Create a heterogeneous list
my_list <- list(
  numbers = c(1, 2, 3),
  text = "Hello R",
  matrix = matrix(1:6, nrow = 2),
  flag = TRUE
)

my_list## $numbers
## [1] 1 2 3
## 
## $text
## [1] "Hello R"
## 
## $matrix
##      [,1] [,2] [,3]
## [1,]    1    3    5
## [2,]    2    4    6
## 
## $flag
## [1] TRUE

heading: 2.9.2 Accessing List Components
text: Lists three main ways access components:
code:
# Method 1: Double brackets [[ ]] - extracts the element itself
my_list[[1]]  # Returns the numeric vector## [1] 1 2 3
# Method 2: Dollar sign $ - access by name
my_list$text  # Returns "Hello R"## [1] "Hello R"
# Method 3: Single brackets [ ] - returns a sublist
my_list[1]    # Returns a list containing the first element## $numbers
## [1] 1 2 3
# Accessing nested elements
my_list[[3]][1, 2]  # Second element of first row in the matrix## [1] 3

heading: 2.9.3 Adding and Removing List Elements
code:
# Adding new components
my_list$new_vector <- c(10, 20, 30)

# Removing components (set to NULL)
my_list$flag <- NULL

# View updated structure
str(my_list)## List of 4
##  $ numbers   : num [1:3] 1 2 3
##  $ text      : chr "Hello R"
##  $ matrix    : int [1:2, 1:3] 1 2 3 4 5 6

heading: 2.16.1 Example 1: Data Cleaning Pipeline
code:
# Create sample data with issues
messy_data <- data.frame(
  id = 1:6,
  value = c(10, 20, NA, 40, 50, 60),
  category = c("A", "B", "A", "C", "B", "A"),
  valid = c(TRUE, TRUE, FALSE, TRUE, TRUE, TRUE)
)

# Function to clean and summarize
clean_and_summarize <- function(df) {
  # Remove invalid rows
  df_clean <- df[df$valid == TRUE, ]

  # Remove missing values
  df_clean <- df_clean[!is.na(df_clean$value), ]

  # Calculate summary by category
  categories <- unique(df_clean$category)
  results <- lapply(categories, function(cat) {
    subset_data <- df_clean[df_clean$category == cat, "value"]
    c(
      category = cat,
      mean = mean(subset_data),
      n = length(subset_data)
    )
  })

  # Combine into data frame
  do.call(rbind, results)
}

clean_and_summarize(messy_data)##      category mean n  
## [1,] "A"      "35" "2"
## [2,] "B"      "35" "2"
## [3,] "C"      "40" "1"

heading: 2.16.2 Example 2: Simulation Study
code:
# Function to simulate and analyze data
simulate_experiment <- function(n_samples, effect_size) {
  # Generate data
  control <- rnorm(n_samples, mean = 100, sd = 15)
  treatment <- rnorm(n_samples, mean = 100 + effect_size, sd = 15)

  # Perform t-test
  test_result <- t.test(treatment, control)

  # Return key results
  list(
    effect_size = effect_size,
    p_value = test_result$p.value,
    significant = test_result$p.value < 0.05
  )
}

# Run simulations for different effect sizes
effect_sizes <- seq(0, 10, by = 2)
simulation_results <- lapply(effect_sizes, function(es) {
  simulate_experiment(n_samples = 50, effect_size = es)
})

# Convert to data frame for easy viewing
results_df <- do.call(rbind, lapply(simulation_results, as.data.frame))
results_df##   effect_size      p_value significant

heading: 3.1 Problem 1: Simple Linear Regression with Intercept
text:
study simple linear regression intercept:\[
Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_i + \varepsilon_i, \qquad = 1, \ldots, n
\]regularity condition \(\sum_{=1}^n (X_i - \bar{X})^2 > 0\) (.e., \(X_i\) equal).Sample means:\[
\bar{Y} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{=1}^n Y_i, \qquad \bar{X} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{=1}^n X_i
\]OLS objective: Minimize sum squared residuals:\[
S(\beta_0, \beta_1) = \sum_{=1}^n \left( Y_i - \beta_0 - \beta_1 X_i \right)^2
\]Definitions:Fitted values: \(\hat{Y}_i = \hat{\beta}_0 + \hat{\beta}_1 X_i\)Residuals: \(\hat{u}_i = Y_i - \hat{Y}_i\)

heading: 3.1.1 Derive the OLS Normal Equations
text:
Differentiate \(S(\beta_0, \beta_1)\) respect \(\beta_0\) \(\beta_1\) set equal zero.First-Order Condition \(\beta_0\):\[
\frac{\partial S}{\partial \beta_0} = -2 \sum_{=1}^n \left( Y_i - \beta_0 - \beta_1 X_i \right) = 0
\]simplifies :\[
\sum_{=1}^n \left( Y_i - \beta_0 - \beta_1 X_i \right) = 0
\]Expanding:\[
\sum_{=1}^n Y_i = n \beta_0 + \beta_1 \sum_{=1}^n X_i
\]Solving \(\beta_0\):\[
\boxed{\hat{\beta}_0 = \bar{Y} - \hat{\beta}_1 \bar{X}}
\]First-Order Condition \(\beta_1\):\[
\frac{\partial S}{\partial \beta_1} = -2 \sum_{=1}^n X_i \left( Y_i - \beta_0 - \beta_1 X_i \right) = 0
\]simplifies :\[
\sum_{=1}^n X_i \left( Y_i - \beta_0 - \beta_1 X_i \right) = 0
\]Derive Slope Centered Form:Substitute \(\beta_0 = \bar{Y} - \beta_1 \bar{X}\) residual expression:\[
Y_i - \beta_0 - \beta_1 X_i = Y_i - (\bar{Y} - \beta_1 \bar{X}) - \beta_1 X_i = (Y_i - \bar{Y}) - \beta_1 (X_i - \bar{X})
\]Minimizing \(\sum_{=1}^n \left[ (Y_i - \bar{Y}) - \beta_1 (X_i - \bar{X}) \right]^2\) respect \(\beta_1\) gives:\[
\sum_{=1}^n (X_i - \bar{X}) \left[ (Y_i - \bar{Y}) - \beta_1 (X_i - \bar{X}) \right] = 0
\]Rearranging:\[
\sum_{=1}^n (X_i - \bar{X})(Y_i - \bar{Y}) = \beta_1 \sum_{=1}^n (X_i - \bar{X})^2
\]OLS Estimators:\[
\boxed{\hat{\beta}_1 = \frac{\sum_{=1}^n (X_i - \bar{X})(Y_i - \bar{Y})}{\sum_{=1}^n (X_i - \bar{X})^2}}
\]\[
\boxed{\hat{\beta}_0 = \bar{Y} - \hat{\beta}_1 \bar{X}}
\]

heading: 3.1.2 Residual Orthogonality Properties
text: key properties follow directly first-order conditions.

heading: 3.1.2.1 Residuals Sum to Zero
text:
FOC \(\beta_0\) evaluated \((\hat{\beta}_0, \hat{\beta}_1)\):\[
\sum_{=1}^n \left( Y_i - \hat{\beta}_0 - \hat{\beta}_1 X_i \right) = 0
\]Therefore:\[
\boxed{\sum_{=1}^n \hat{u}_i = 0}
\]

heading: 3.1.2.2 Residuals are Orthogonal to \(X\)
text:
FOC \(\beta_1\) evaluated \((\hat{\beta}_0, \hat{\beta}_1)\):\[
\sum_{=1}^n X_i \left( Y_i - \hat{\beta}_0 - \hat{\beta}_1 X_i \right) = 0
\]Therefore:\[
\boxed{\sum_{=1}^n X_i \hat{u}_i = 0}
\]

heading: 3.1.2.3 Residuals are Orthogonal to \((X_i - \bar{X})\)
text:
Using result \(\sum_{=1}^n \hat{u}_i = 0\):\[
\sum_{=1}^n (X_i - \bar{X}) \hat{u}_i = \sum_{=1}^n X_i \hat{u}_i - \bar{X} \sum_{=1}^n \hat{u}_i = 0 - \bar{X} \cdot 0 = 0
\]Therefore:\[
\boxed{\sum_{=1}^n (X_i - \bar{X}) \hat{u}_i = 0}
\]

heading: 3.1.3.1 The Regression Line Passes Through \((\bar{X}, \bar{Y})\)
3.1.3.2 Mean Residual is Zero
3.1.4 Decomposition of Variation (TSS = ESS + RSS)
text: Definitions:

heading: 3.1.4.1 Decomposition
text:
Start :\[
Y_i - \bar{Y} = (\hat{Y}_i - \bar{Y}) + (Y_i - \hat{Y}_i) = (\hat{Y}_i - \bar{Y}) + \hat{u}_i
\]Square sides sum:\[
\sum_{=1}^n (Y_i - \bar{Y})^2 = \sum_{=1}^n (\hat{Y}_i - \bar{Y})^2 + \sum_{=1}^n \hat{u}_i^2 + 2 \sum_{=1}^n (\hat{Y}_i - \bar{Y}) \hat{u}_i
\]

heading: 3.1.4.2 The Cross-Term Vanishes
text:
Note :\[
\hat{Y}_i - \bar{Y} = (\hat{\beta}_0 + \hat{\beta}_1 X_i) - \bar{Y} = (\bar{Y} - \hat{\beta}_1 \bar{X} + \hat{\beta}_1 X_i) - \bar{Y} = \hat{\beta}_1 (X_i - \bar{X})
\]Therefore:\[
\sum_{=1}^n (\hat{Y}_i - \bar{Y}) \hat{u}_i = \hat{\beta}_1 \sum_{=1}^n (X_i - \bar{X}) \hat{u}_i = \hat{\beta}_1 \cdot 0 = 0
\]

heading: 3.1.4.3 Result
3.1.5.1 Sample Covariance Between \(X\) and \(\hat{u}\) is Zero
text:
Since \(\sum_{=1}^n \hat{u}_i = 0\), sample covariance \(X\) \(\hat{u}\) proportional :\[
\sum_{=1}^n (X_i - \bar{X}) \hat{u}_i = 0
\]Therefore:\[
\boxed{\widehat{\text{Cov}}(X, \hat{u}) = 0}
\]

heading: 3.1.6 Fitted Values are Orthogonal to Residuals
text:
\[
\sum_{=1}^n \hat{Y}_i \hat{u}_i = \sum_{=1}^n (\hat{Y}_i - \bar{Y}) \hat{u}_i + \bar{Y} \sum_{=1}^n \hat{u}_i = 0 + \bar{Y} \cdot 0 = 0
\]Therefore:\[
\boxed{\sum_{=1}^n \hat{Y}_i \hat{u}_i = 0}
\]
